title: Hafslund Sesam - an archive on semantics
segmentation: Hello everybody, I have only 30 minutes and a lot to tell you so I'm just gonna dive straight in.
Um?
This project probably stands out a bit at this conference because it's.
A 100% commercial project it's there was a business.
They had a business need.
They did a contract with us and we built a semantic web type system to fulfill their need.
It's an archive system.
It won our Norwegian archive of the year 2012.
Both because of the functionality and because of how it was built.
Oh they spent.
Some millions of Norwegian kroner on this project.
The customer says that the project is already paid for itself.
They've already recouped the expense and savings at the document center, so that's pretty good.
The reason I think it's worth coming to a conference like this to present it is that to build this with traditional technology.
I don't think we could have done it, so we really needed either RDF or something very very similar to build this project.
Probably.
No, you know the customer hoflin it's a conglomerate of companies mainly focused on energy production and trading.
They also run the electricity grid in Norway in the region around Oslo.
They also do remotely thing and lots of other stuff.
They have a huge set of documents.
Said they run the electricity grid an for a single set of pylons holding wires.
There can be 1000 documents an you can imagine the number of pilots right?
And then come the power stations transformation stations and that's just a grid.
Then you have correspondence with customers and loud alarm.
So it's a huge set of documents.
Their goals was they needed a new archive.
They wanted better metadata quality.
They wanted a higher percentage of documents archived.
And they wanted to use a friendly way to find the documents.
Pretty straightforward, but we got some questions on this paper.
Why didn't we look at existing archive solutions and the answer to that is pretty simple.
In Norway we have a standard called Nordic.
This comes out of a couple of centuries of tradition in how to do journals.
Basically, correspondence journals in the public sector.
So there's a very rigid standard that your metadata must follow.
An in fact, you have to use a system that must be approved by the Norwegian Archive authorities.
Basically so this only like.
For real solutions to choose between.
And as you can imagine from that, four solutions, we're about 5 million people in the country.
There's not a lot of competition, so these systems are.
I don't think it's an exaggeration to say that they are hated.
And that is why in fact we were brought in to do this because in a sense, the purpose of the project is to hide.
The government approved archive system from the users right so they work in the system that they're working.
They don't work in the archive system, right?
They're working in the ERP system, customer relation system, whatever.
They produce some document and they want it to go into the archive without having to see the archive.
And later, because the archive is absolutely awful at searching.
They want to be able to find the document again without going into the archive.
So, and this is a recurring problem, both that.
People skip archiving documents because it's such a pain.
And they have a, you know, lots and lots of old-fashioned fields to fill in, so they don't.
So you wind up with really poor metadata.
An aloe set of documents archive.
Does this.
Matter well, actually it does.
The archive is the official record of everything the company is doing right.
So you're in fact you reckon they required by the government to put stuff in an I said they are a commercial company, but the part that runs the electricity grid is a monopolist.
So they that part of the company is required to follow the standard and so they decided they would all do it to have a single archive for the whole organization.
And when you've gone to all the trouble right there, collecting all this important information, it seems.
A shame really, to let let the thing turn into a black hole where stuff disappears and you never see it again.
And also.
Suddenly you want to you want to build a power line, right?
Somebody knows that?
Yes, we did.
We did the contract that lets us build it across this piece of land, but we can't find the contract that's going to be 10,000,000 kroner to Windows straight away.
So the archive doesn't matter at all until suddenly becomes the most important thing in the universe, right?
So what we were trying to do was make it easy to archive the documents.
We want you to be able to archive the documents within the system you're working in, which if it's the ERP system, if it's SharePoint.
And we want to reuse the metadata from there so that you don't have to re type it.
Um?
And we also want to enrich the metadata.
Automatically, we want to make it possible to find the documents again and we want the documents to be connected to the business context, right?
Typically in the archive you have, you have a document you have some fields, that's it.
We wanted to really be connected with the business context that it came from.
So.
We're going to go into the system itself.
I stole this slide from the customer because I think it's interesting that this is how the customer sees what they bought.
And as a consultant, this makes me very happy because.
Believe me, it's not every time that the customer knows what they bought, but in this case they do.
You see the row at the top here?
That's the applications that people are working in, right?
So they produced their document here by send it to this cloud and then Norwegian text here says automatic application of metadata, right?
And stop and think now for a moment right?
I send in a work order.
If the system is supposed to know that this is related to a specific particular customer, how can the system know that?
How can you usefully add metadata?
You really need to have background knowledge, So what we've done is the cloud that you see over on the right hand side here.
Which is basically data extracted from all of these systems and gathered into an RDF database.
And that's how we're able to say that, oh, you sent us the work order 123.
Well, I know that's for customer XY zed because it says right here in the ERP system.
So that's how we're able to add the metadata.
And then the government approved archives.
It's down here.

But it's not more people use when they find the documents, because that's the user interface over here, which is something we built with a search engine called recommend a commercial search engine so that indexes are.
Both the metadata that we gathered.
And the documents.
That's basically the system.
There's a little bit more to it.
In technical terms.
We took data from these three systems.
And we use the protocol that I will return to called SD share to copy it over into Virtuoso, the Triple Store that we use.
This is against fashion.
I know we should be using R2, RML and query Federation and all of that stuff but we have.
600 million statements we have who knows how many IT systems.
And.
In order to be able to add the metadata automatically, we need to be able to do at least 20 queries a second.
Alright with query Federation I don't think so also.
The ERP system is way overloaded.
We're not allowed to just bang it with queries when we feel like it.
So there are architectural constraints here.
So basically that approach is no go.
We can't do that.
So we copy the data into the triplestore.
Then some of that using the same protocol gets pulled into the archive.
What we're doing is we're taking the Contacts, customers and so on and copying them into the archive because the archive is a Journal of documents received and sent right?
So when you when you get a document, you say who it's from or who it's too.
And then you can go into the archive and you can see all the documents sent to this particular customer.
Can we reuse?
The customer data from up here.
Then we pull back.
You know we put it into your card, but the archive doesn't know that.
This stuff came from elsewhere, so we record in the Triple Store that actually customer 123 in the archive was customer 456 in the ERP system.
Then the search engine uses SD shared to index up both the Triple Store and the documents from the archives was fairly straightforward, so when somebody.
Sense in a document this can be from one of the applications or it can be documents that were scanned by the Document Center.
It gets sent to a seamless server that we built.
See Miss is an Oasis Standard 4.
CNS Systems standard interface basically.
So we use that because we want all of the interfaces to be standardized.
We run the sparkle queries against the Triple Store to add more metadata and to translate these archive systems.
They also tend to do things like if you put this document into this part of the archive, a certain field must be set to 7.
Why must it be set to 7?
Who knows if you don't have it set for anything, the archive will say no.
Sorry, not going to accept this document, so we do that for you.
If you send in something that the archive is not going to accept, we fill in all the bits that are missing.
That's also done by the sparkle queries and then finally goes into the archive.
Um?
I'm going to talk a little bit about how we extracted the data.
We went against fashion in.
Part 2 there's no Canonical data model, right?
We take the data as it is in the source.
And we just transfer it.
We make no attempt to rewrite it to a common model.
The reason is that these ID systems will come and go.
And they will not have models that are compatible.
So we decided, well, we're just going to deal with that.
We're going to take the data as it is.
We're going to make the best use of it that we can.
If honestly simplifies data extraction.
It also means that we can plug and play data sources as we like.
We do have a core ontology and we try to we make one ontology per source system.
We try to subtype is from the core one where it's possible it's not always possible.
Oh, this is just to show you this sort of data that's in here.
We have a work order that may say something like repair Pilon 123.
That may be part of a project.
Maybe work for a customer.
You might say what equipment it's work on and the equipment objects are arranged into a hierarchy so you can drill down and find specific pieces you have employees, department's companies.
Customers and suppliers.
Basically, um.
In the Triple Store there is one graph per data source, so data from the ERP system is in one graph.
All the data from the archive is in another, and so on and so forth.
Where there are shared identifiers.
We put in same mass links across the sources.
Typically things like equipment objects, work orders, things like that.
They have common IDs, but a number of things don't.
And that's a bit of a problem.
In the ERP system there is a table called customers.
That's great, except that of course the people typing in the customers they don't really care about duplicates, right?
They just want all the bills paid.
So University of Oslo appears 14 times in the customers table.
Not so good.
This is suppliers table.
What do you know?
Some of the customers are suppliers too.
Who duplicates?

I live near Oslo.
I'm in the CRM system twice, once with the correct address once with the wrong address.

You want one.

Record linkage engine that we built this part of the project.

The state that keeps changing, right?
It changes all the time.
So we needed something that could listen for just the changes, update with respect to that, and then feedback what's changed.
So we built our own.
It wasn't really that hard.

I'll same as links.
An officer in Cologne, possibly same as links in case we're not sure.

And there are other uses.
The automatic tagging.
Here's my example with the work order.
Basically what we're doing is we're repeating sparkle queries.
Until we reach transitive closure and no more tags are added.
And what we do is we annotate the RDF properties.
That we want to follow to fight to get new tags.

We do want the project.
We don't want the manager of the project, but we do want the customer.

We just.

So the sparkle queries is generic.
It's the same query no matter what.
And this also contributes to being able to add and remove data sources as we like, right?
We don't have to change the queries, we only have to change the annotations.

This data is not published in fact.

A lot of it is secret for various reasons so.

So the search results.
Do you get or only the search results that you actually have the rights to see and the way we do that is that when we extract the source data, we also extract the user writes.
Basically the list of who is allowed to see it.

The ERP system is a very straightforward model for this, you just mind the couple of tables and that's it.
The archive system.

It's the foundation of the whole project in one sense, in addition to the Triple Store, is this SD share program protocol that we used to move the data around?
You can think of it as RSS or Atom for RDF data.
So basically gives you feed of the data that's changed in a collection.
What is a collection you decide it can be a graph or it can be like when we do deduplication.
We say every customer or supplier from these systems.
Basically, provides two things you can get.
A snapshot of an entire collection that's to get started, right?
You do that the first time afterwards.
You can then ask for just the resources that have changed since the last time you asked.
So in fact, to implement Anesta share serve.
You need two things.
Three things you need to be able to list all the objects in the data set.
You need to find the list of resources they've changed since sometime.
And you need to be able to dump each resource to RDF.
That's it.
That's the whole thing.
So it means that we built a solution that's completely different.
Generic, right?
There's just one interface, and it's always the same one.
There's an SD share client that I didn't draw in the architecture, but all of the arrows are effectively implemented by by the client.
It takes a list of.
These are the SD share sources that we want to pull from.
This is where we want them to go.
That's it, it's done.
We're trying to make SD share a kind of standard.
We're not the standard spotted where we try to make it a kind of open standard anyway, and this W 3C Community groups dedicated to it.
5 minutes OK. How?
This is basically the structure of a nested share service.
There's an Atom feed that basically gives you a list of all the collections.
Then for each collection there is another field and there has always 2 links, one to the snapshot feed and wanted the fragment feed.
Usually the snapshot feed gives you just a dump of the data as it is right now, but you could have many snapshots going back in time if you want.
And then there's a fragment feed that's just a list.
Two of the resources that have changed and it really uses the rest hypertext principle.
Right, you go in here and you can navigate the whole thing.
Just by following the links when you subscribe to a collection, usually you give the client the URL to this.
Then you can find the snapshots.
You can find the fragments and so on.
Oh OK, so how do we implement the fragmente feed?
On the ERP system.
There is a table called history log.
I has a list of everything that's changed in the ERP system, so that's really simple.
It's just a SQL query against that.
Give us the objects, the types of the objects and when they changed.
Oh and filter by sometime.
And we turn that into.
An Atom feed basically one entry for each resource.
And there will be.
I need to be in two places at once.
There will be in the link here.
To the audio for that resource.
Down here is the link to the next one.
Um?
The client is built so that you can plug in different frontends and backends.
At the moment we have two backends.
One is a sparkle back end, so it will take the data that's changed and will update a sparkle database, whatever it is.
We also implemented a generic HTTP protocol.
That we use for we tried that solar for example.
So we use this service to do solar indexing.
RDF data.
We can we use it for other things as well.
Yeah, here's the screenshot.
Getting data from.
Triplestore like when we want the.
All the Contacts that have changed, that's just a sparkle query.
We set up a sparkle query in the XML configuration of this SD share server, that's it.
Now we can pull out all the data that's changed and apply it on the other side.
So.
We get a system that's uniform.
Everything is done one way.
All the integrations are really simple loose bindings you can add and remove components.
No state.
None of the integrations have any state at all.
The state is basically just a time in the West History client that is the last time we updated.
You can add fragments one time more times, same effect.
If we need to, we can just wipe out the data for the OS for one of the systems and reload it winding up.
Yeah.
This is applicable to a lot more than just this system.
We built 3 four more systems in different ways, what?
We use RDF.
Because it's schema less so we can add and remove data sources.
There's a generic syntax so data can flow in the same format.
No type, no matter what type of data it is.
First class support for identity with same as and it's standardized.
We used were also, but we don't have to.
We can switch if we want.
I see people complaining that you know if you want to build a standard domain model in Java with domain model objects and you sparkle that's hard.
Yeah, maybe it is hard, but you're doing it wrong.
You shouldn't be doing it that way.
You shouldn't be using RDF if you intend to do it the old fashioned way.
Um?
There's a lot more to this project.
Run your neck.
You're carrying the paper that has more details.
If you go to slideshare.net Lawrence J, there's a.
2 hour version of this talk that also has more detail.
Thank you.
